question: Which of the following hypothalamic nuclei regulates circadian rhythms?

A boy who was pushed down the hill during a fight with his friends is brought to the emergency department with a head injury. On examination, a hematoma is seen between the skull base and dura mater. Which of the following arteries is involved?
Which of the following key enzymes is required for the synthesis of acetylcholine?
What is the inability to perform alternating movements known as?

A 60-year-old hypertensive male was taken to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset of nausea and vomiting. The examination revealed slurred speech and dysmetria on finger-to-nose test on the left side. However, his gait was normal. In which of the following areas lesion has occurred?

A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) shows damage to the corticospinal tract on one side. Which of the following tract serves as an "alternative pathway" for transmitting motor signals to the spinal cord?
The sweat glands and piloerector muscles of hairy skin are innervated by which of the following fiber types?
Which type of cholinergic receptor is found at synapses between preganglionic and postganglionic neurons of the sympathetic system?
Which of the following conditions is associated with low levels of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA)?

A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency room after he suffers a head injury in a road traffic accident. It is observed that he has flailing movement in his left upper limb. Which of the following structures is the most likely site of lesion in this case?
Which of the following types of neurons innervate extrafusal muscle fibers?
Which of the following types of nerve fibers innervate Golgi tendon organs?
Which of the following is an opioid receptor antagonist used as a drug for opioid overdose and toxicity?
Which of the following veins is not a tributary of the cavernous sinus?
Which of the following veins drains into the superior sagittal sinus?
Which of the following cranial nerves does not originate at the pontomedullary junction of the brainstem?
Which of the following arteries is not a part of the circle of Willis?
Which of the following statements regarding the long association fibers is incorrect?

answers.option: The cingulum is an example of long association fibers
Superior longitudinal fasciculus is the largest bundle of nerve fibers
Lie deep beneath the cerebral cortex

question: A 44-year-old patient presents to the outpatient clinic with the complaint of being unable to recall any recently occurring events. Which of the following brain structures is responsible for converting short-term memory into long-term memory?

A 67-year-old male patient admitted to the neurology ward is observed to have intention tremor and cerebellar ataxia. Radiological scans reveal a pontine infarct. Which of the following fibers is most likely damaged in this case?
Which of the following is not a feature of postganglionic neurons of the sympathetic nervous system?

answers.option: Originate away from the effector organs
The cell bodies of postganglionic neurons are in autonomic ganglia located peripherally

question: A 62-year-old male patient is diagnosed with early-stage Parkinson's disease. The neurological examination reveals a slight resting tremor of the left hand, slow gait, and lack of the normal range of facial expression. Which of the following is the most likely site of the degenerative changes at this stage of the patient's disease?
Which of the following structures forms the anterior boundary of the interventricular foramen of Monro?

A 50-year-old male patient undergoes a CT scan which reveals a tumor of the midbrain. It shows symmetrical distension of the lateral ventricles and the third ventricle. Which of the following structures is most likely obstructed by the tumor in this case?

A 53-year-old patient was brought to the emergency department after a fall. MRI scan reveals a slipped disc at the L3 level. Neurological examination shows that the patient has a bilateral loss of pain, temperature, and light touch sensation below the level of the lesion, bilateral lower motor neuron paralysis in the segment of the lesion, and bilateral spastic paralysis below the level of the lesion. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

The sensation of discriminative touch, vibratory sense, and conscious muscle joint proprioception of the lower limbs passes from the posterior root ganglia to the postcentral gyrus through which of the following pathways?

answers.option: Lateral spinothalamic and medial lemniscus pathway
Lateral spinothalamic and spinal lemniscus pathway
Fasciculus gracilis and medial lemniscus pathway
Fasciculus gracilis and spinal lemniscus pathway
Anterior spinothalamic and spinal lemniscus pathway

question: Which of the following embryological structures gives rise to the dorsal sensory horn of the spinal cord?
A parasympathetic nerve arising from the brainstem influences the lungs. The cell body of this nerve lies in which of the following nuclei?

A 24-year-old patient presents to the emergency department after a road accident with complaints of headache, nausea, vomiting & an altered level of consciousness. An X-ray of the skull reveals a fracture of the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone. Which of the following cranial nerves passes through the foramina of this fractured bone?

During a routine examination of a newborn baby in the pediatric clinic, the physician notices a depression of the anterior fontanelle (membranous gap in between bones of the skull). The depressed fontanelle lies between which of the following bones?

answers.option: Parietal and petrous part of temporal bone
Parietal and mastoid part of temporal bone

question: A patient who suffered from a road traffic accident is brought to the emergency room with a skull fracture involving bones of the anterior cranial fossa. Which of the following skull bones is most likely to be fractured in this case?

A diabetic patient is observed to have mydriasis while undergoing an examination in an ophthalmology clinic. All other eye movements are normal. The nerve most likely affected in this case arises from which of the following brain stem nuclei?

A neonate is diagnosed with obstructive hydrocephalus. The parents were counseled and told that this condition is due to the blockage of a conduit between two ventricles of the brain. Which of the following is the most likely conduit obstructed in this case?

An unconscious male patient is brought to the emergency room. An MRI of the brain is performed and reveals infarction of the medial surface of the cerebral hemispheres. Which of the following cortical areas is likely to be affected in this case?

A patient suffers from a gunshot wound injuring his spinal cord on the left side. The patient now has loss of pain and temperature sensation on the right side of the body. Which of the following tracts is likely to be affected in this case?
A cross-section of the cerebellum shows the cerebellar nuclei embedded in the white matter which is surrounded by the cortex. Which of the following nuclei is located most medially?

During a lecture on the basal nuclei, the professor mentions a part of the corpus striatum which is associated with the lateral ventricle medially and the internal capsule laterally. Which of the following structures of the corpus striatum is being mentioned?
The two parietal bones form the sides and the roof of the skull and articulate with each other in the midline. Which of the following sutures is present between these bones?
Within the cerebellar cortex, a basket-like nest is formed around the soma of which of the following cells?
The cerebellar cortex is composed of three layers. Which of the following layers is a synaptic zone that is mainly composed of dendritic arborizations of Purkinje cells?
During the development of the spinal cord, the central canal is lined by three layers. Which of the three layers contains cell bodies of neurons?

During the 5th week of development, five brain swellings appear. These include the telencephalon, diencephalon, mesencephalon, metencephalon, and myelencephalon. The mesencephalon gives rise to which of the following structures?
The speed of a nerve impulse is independent of which of the following factors?

A 20-year-old male was walking barefoot when he suddenly withdrew his leg when he accidentally stepped on a nail. Which of the following reflexes is responsible for activating the antagonistic contralateral extensor muscles in this case?

During a study, the response of a particular reflex is inhibited for a while and then released suddenly, resulting in a response that is stronger than normal. This is known as which of the following properties of a reflex?

A 55-year-old male presented to the neurology clinic with the complaint of excessive daytime sleepiness. He was advised to undergo a sleep study. Just after midnight, the lab technician notices the EEG wave showing K complexes and sleep spindles. Which of the following stages of sleep is the patient in at that moment?
Which of the following neurotransmitters is released by the Raphe neurons nerve endings is associated with the induction of sleep?
Which of the following parts of the cerebellum is involved in the planning of sequential movements?
Which of the following cerebellar disorders results in an inability to combine the various components of a movement to create a smooth action?
The type B nerve fibers are the most sensitive to which of the following stimuli?
Which of the following nuclei of the basal ganglia receives input from the sub-thalamus via the indirect pathway?

A 66-year-old male patient suffers from a cerebrovascular accident resulting in a complete loss of sensation on the right side of the body sparing the head and face. Which of the following nuclei of the thalamus is most likely to be affected by this lesion?
Which of the following brain waves are most likely to be present in the EEG of a healthy sleeping person and a brain-damaged awake person?

A 40-year-old woman suffers from a cut injuring a peripheral nerve. The distance between the two ends of the damaged nerve is less than 3 mm. Which of the following cells is responsible for the regeneration of this nerve?
A neurologist plans to conduct a study on the properties of sensory neurons. Which of the following types of neurons is most appropriate for this study?

A 2-year-old boy developed flaccid paralysis after being infected with poliovirus. Poliovirus enters the central nervous system from peripheral nerves and reaches the soma by retrograde transport. Which of the following proteins is used by the virus to reach the cell body?

In an experimental lab, multiple stimuli from different neurons are applied to a post-synaptic neuron simultaneously to generate an action potential. Which one of the following phenomena of a synapse is displayed here?
Which of the following types of inhibition is mediated by inhibitory interneurons in the spinal cord and tends to produce the effect of lateral inhibition?

A 42-year-old jackhammer operator presents in the neurology clinic with decreased sensitivity to high-frequency vibrations in the non-hairy skin of his hands. Which of the following receptors is most likely affected in this case?
The brain can distinguish between the strengths of light touch and sustained pressure during sensory encoding. Which of the following properties is responsible for this action of the brain?

A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department with head trauma after he fell from a ladder. A physician shines a flashlight into the patient's eyes and observes that the pupillary reflexes are normal. This reflex is used to test the functioning of which of the following structures of the brain?
The lateral lemniscus is part of a pathway carrying which of the following sensations?

A 72-year-old female patient presents to the outpatient clinic with the complaint of being unable to raise her shoulders and turn her head. Investigations reveal a lesion in the medulla. Which of the following cranial nerves is most likely to be affected by this lesion?
Which of the following functions of the brain is affected when there is damage to the peri-aqueductal gray area of the midbrain?

answers.option: Arousal and alertness of the cerebral cortex
Coordination of head and neck movements

question: A 60-year-old male patient is suspected to be suffering from impairment of the otolith organs based on a detailed neurological examination and a CT scan. Which of the following functions is most likely to be disturbed in this case?

answers.option: Prediction of disequilibrium of body with a sudden turn
Rotation of head to one side
Recognition of angular acceleration of head
Detection of the position of the head with respect to gravity

question: In an animal laboratory, the change in the behavior of a monkey is observed. The monkey has a loss of fear, forgetfulness, and the tendency to place everything in its mouth. Ablation of which of the following structures of the limbic system is the most likely cause for these behavioral changes?

A 45-year-old male presented to a neurology clinic with complaints of spontaneous and continuous writhing movement of hands, an arm, and face. MRI scans reveal a lesion of the globus pallidus. The patient is manifesting which of the following signs in this case?
The myelin sheath of the neurons is altered due to the formation of plaques in which of the following disorders of the nervous system?
Which of the following cranial nerves are a part of the parasympathetic nervous system?

Before a minor surgical procedure, a local anesthetic is injected by the surgeon to ensure that the patient feels no pain. Which of the following nerve fibers is most likely to be blocked by the local anesthetic?
Which of the following substances is released by interneurons in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord to inhibit ascending pain signals?
During voluntary movements, the Golgi tendon organs are involved in providing which of the following information to the central nervous system?

answers.option: Length of the muscle being moved
Change in the joint angle produced by movement
Tension developed in the muscle being moved

question: Which of the following hormones or factors is responsible for inhibiting the action of leptin on the ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus and stimulating the lateral hypothalamic nucleus producing a sense of hunger?
Which of the following mechanisms is involved in the conversion of short-term memory to long-term memory?

A 45-year-old male patient suffering from a head injury undergoes a neurological examination. The neurologist observes that the patient can understand both spoken and written words but his speech is slow, poorly articulated, and requires significant effort. Which of the following areas of the cerebral cortex is most likely to be damaged in this case?
The deficiency of which of the following vitamins is marked by anemia, impaired neurotransmitter production, increased homocysteine levels, and neuronal demyelination?
Which of the following vitamins is required for the synthesis of neurotransmitters like dopamine, serotonin, and GABA?
In the blood-brain barrier, the endothelial cells are tightly packed together by means of tight junctions that are formed by which of the following specialized transmembrane proteins?
Which of the following compounds crosses the blood-brain barrier by means of receptor-mediated transcytosis?
Parkinson's disease is associated with the loss of specific neurons containing which of the following neurotransmitters?
A cobweb coagulum is a characteristic finding on CSF examination in which of the following conditions?

A 39-year-old female patient presents to the outpatient department with a severe headache for the last 3 days. On physical examination, she is afebrile and normotensive. Fundoscopic examination shows papilledema in the right eye. She was admitted to the hospital for further testing. A day later, she develops right pupillary dilation with impaired ocular movement. These findings are best explained by which of the following lesions?

A female infant born after a full-term pregnancy weighing 3.4kg has an enlarged head with the occipitofrontal circumference (OFC) being 49.5 cm. A cranial ultrasound reveals bilateral ventriculomegaly. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old male who has a history of HIV is admitted to the neurology ward with signs and symptoms of encephalitis. Which of the following is a characteristic histopathological finding of HIV encephalitis?

answers.option: Microglial nodules and multinucleated giant cells

question: Which of the following is not a risk factor for encephalitis?

answers.option: People with a strong immune system
Children under the age of 1 year
People with a weak immune system

question: A 50-year-old female patient who is a known case of an autoimmune disorder visits the neurology clinic with complaints of fatigue, tingling, numbness, muscle weakness, and muscle spasms. CSF analysis reveals oligoclonal bands. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

A 5-month-old boy is brought to the outpatient clinic with complaints of global developmental delay, generalized weakness of the body, and jerky eye movement. There is also a family history of his 5-year-old brother having the same complaints. MRI scans of the brain reveal symmetrical lesions. Genetic studies reveal a mutation in the ABCD1 gene located at the X chromosome. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 5-year-old boy is admitted to the neurology ward with complaints of headache, photophobia, and neck rigidity. He is a suspected case of meningitis. Which of the following is the best diagnostic investigation for meningitis?
A 1-year-old girl is diagnosed with bacterial meningitis. Which of the following findings in the CSF analysis are suggestive of bacterial meningitis?

A young male patient presents to the emergency department in an unconscious state. The parents give a history of him swimming in a pool for the last few days. CSF analysis reveals small flask-shaped amoeba. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

A 60-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension for the last 10 years is brought to the emergency department in an unconscious state. History also reveals that the patient is non-compliant with his medication for hypertension. MRI and CT scan brain show a lobar hemorrhage. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this condition?
Which of the following is an inhibitory neurotransmitter that causes hyperpolarization of neurons?
The analgesic properties of opioids are primarily mediated by which of the following receptors?
A 36-year-old man is hired as a laboratory worker and he will be handling Rabies related viruses and vaccines. Which of the following vaccines is he advised to get?

A 32-year-old mother of two children visits a primary healthcare center with complaints of feeling sad, irritable, and empty, and often finds herself crying for no reason for the past three months. She has a loss of interest in all activities and finds it really hard to carry out her daily activities. She feels as if she would be better off dead and even has thoughts about taking her life at times. Which one of the following disorders is she most likely suffering from?
Which of the following terms refers to the constant presence of a disease or infectious agent within its usual or expected frequency in a given geographical area or population group?

Polio is now endemic in only 2 countries; Pakistan and Afghanistan. Two very effective polio vaccines, the oral and injectable vaccines are being given in the EPI program, and in addition, special immunization campaigns are repeatedly conducted all over Pakistan to eradicate polio. In the routine EPI schedule, which of the following is the correct age for the administration of the injectable polio vaccine (IPV)?

John diverts his attention to stop thinking about disturbing events in order to prevent himself from experiencing any overwhelming negative emotions. Which of the following term best corresponds to this strategy?

During a flood, a mental health professional is given the responsibility to provide psychological first aid and conduct crisis intervention. Which of the following is the 7th and last stage of the crisis intervention model?

answers.option: Plan and conduct a crisis intervention
Develop and formulate an action plan

question: A 60-year-old male, presents to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset of nausea and vomiting. The examination revealed slurred speech and dysmetria on finger-to-nose test on the left side. However, his gait was normal. In which of the following areas lesion has occurred?
A boy kicked a ball, stretching his muscle spindles. Which of the following fibers will take these nerve signals toward the spinal cord?
Unmyelinated basket cells send fibers to which cells to surround them?
The Great Vein of Galen is formed by the union of which of the following veins?

answers.option: Superior cerebral veins and inferior cerebral veins
Anterior cerebral veins and posterior cerebral veins
Inferior sagittal sinus and straight sinus
Internal cerebral veins and basal veins of Rosenthal
Middle cerebral veins and transverse sinus

question: In the development of the diencephalon, three swellings form around a ventricle for the thalamus, hypothalamus, and epithalamus. Which ventricle is this?
A woman develops right-sided body weakness at night that later resolves. The next morning she comes to the clinic concerned about what happened. What could be the cause?
Which of the following is at risk of damage due to fracture of the pterion?
Pill rolling tremors at rest are a characteristic sign of which disease?
A patient presents with complaints of vertigo and positional nystagmus. Which part of the cerebellum is most likely damaged?
A patient with a history of measles presents with slow progressive demyelination of nerve fibers. Which of the following disorders best explains these symptoms?
Which of the following modulates pain in both pre-and post-ganglionic neurons?
Which part of the ventricular system is mostly commonly involved in producing non-communicating hydrocephalus?
Strong stimulation of the punishment centers of the brain results in?

A parent brought her child to the neurology clinic because he was achieving under-expected results in reading. The neurologist examined the child and found that the child could see the words, and tell that those words meant something but was unable to interpret them. What is the most probable diagnosis?
Which of the following best describes retrograde amnesia?
Which of the following regions of the spinal cord is affected in a patient with polio?
A baby is born with low birth weight, and a CT scan shows periventricular calcification. Which infection is most likely responsible for this finding?
Which of the following actions would cause maximum excitation of hair cells in the right horizontal semicircular canal?

answers.option: Keeping the head still in a car moving with no acceleration
Rotation of head to the right
Tipping of head to the left
Movement of head in the vertical plane

question: Which part of the brain controls stereotyped motor activity?
Lesion of which of the following structures presents with flinging movements of the limbs?

A patient presents with severe aphasia and hemiparesis of the right limbs and face. However, the face is affected more than the lower limbs. Which of the following options best explains these symptoms?
Which of the following structures of the occipital bone provides attachment to the pharyngeal raphe?

answers.option: Superior basilar part of the occipital bone

question: Which nucleus of the brain stem controls full-body equilibrium?
A patient presents with cavernous sinus thrombosis. Which cranial nerve is least likely to be affected?

A man had an accident in which he hit the front windshield of his vehicle. MRI showed minor cerebral contusion but he had no symptoms until after a month when he presented to the clinic with headaches, irritability, and was acting strangely. Which cerebrovascular condition best explains these symptoms?

A lady who is addicted to her phone presents to the clinic with a headache and blurred vision. The doctor diagnoses a benign tumor of the meninges present in the anterior cranial fossa. Which of the following structures is not present in this fossa?
When a medical student performs a deep tendon reflex test such as the patellar reflex, which afferent nerve fiber directly synapses with the motor neuron that innervates the muscle being tested?
Which of the following is the function of the caudate's connection with the cortex (caudate circuit)?
A hypertensive patient presents with paralysis, and an infarction of the posterior limb of the internal capsule is found. Which fibers are affected?
Which of the following types of brain wave is recorded in alert wakefulness?
Damage to which area of the brain can cause alexia and agraphia?
Which of the following is deficient in Alzheimer's disease?
A fracture of the pterion is most likely to damage which artery?
A patient presents with a "pill-rolling" tremor at rest in the right hand. Which of the following diseases is most likely?
A decrease in serotonin is most likely to cause which of the following conditions?
Tryptophan deficiency leads to which of the following disorders?
According to the World Health Organization (WHO), which of the following is the most important method in eradicating and controlling polio?

answers.option: Mass immunization of children in vulnerable age groups

question: Which of the following opioid agonists is used to treat diarrhea?
Basket and stellate cells synapse with which type of cell in the cerebellum?
Before performing any movement, which area of the cerebrum creates a mental image of the motion that needs to be performed?
According to the WHO 2001 guidelines for mental health education, what is the recommended approach for better mental health in the community?

answers.option: Increasing mental health awareness in the community
Promoting inpatient care over outpatient care

question: Which of the following nerves is most likely to get injured during forceps delivery?
Into which venous sinus does the inferior sagittal sinus drain?

A 24-year-old man fell down the stairs during a fight and lost consciousness. After regaining consciousness, he visited a restaurant but lost consciousness again while eating, about an hour later. Upon being taken to the ER, a CT scan of the brain was performed. Physical examination revealed fixed and dilated pupils. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 65-year-old woman with a history of hypertension suddenly experienced right-sided loss of sensation while she was watching television in the evening. She noticed the numbness and weakness lasted for about 20 minutes but gradually improved, and by the time she went to bed, she felt completely normal. The next morning, she had no lingering symptoms but was concerned about what had happened. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A patient presents with complaints of forgetting daily events. A brain scan reveals a lesion. Which part of the brain is most likely affected?
A cordotomy was performed to relieve pain in the left leg of a man. Which tract must have been removed?
In the development of the diencephalon, three swellings form around a ventricle for the thalamus, hypothalamus, and epithalamus. Which part of the ventricular system is this?
Which of the following bones are paired?
